questions.text: Below is a radioactive scan for thyroid pathology. which of the following is the most probable diagnosis: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypersecreting Adenoma

 

Image findings are suggestive of hypersecreting adenoma.

 

  1. Increased uptake in the right lobe at the thyroid
  2. Suppressed uptake in left lobe of thyroid

 

These findings are highly suggestive of a hypersecreting adenoma. This condition occurs when a benign tumor in the thyroid gland produces thyroid hormone independently of the normal regulatory mechanisms, leading to an overactive area (hot spot) in one part of the thyroid, with suppression of activity in the rest of the gland due to negative feedback mechanisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid: Incorrect as this type of cancer typically presents with a "cold nodule," which shows reduced or no uptake on a radioactive scan. The scan shows no areas of reduced uptake indicative of a cold nodule.

 

Option C. Grave’s disease: Incorrect because Grave's disease generally causes a diffuse increase in uptake across the entire thyroid gland due to widespread stimulation of thyroid tissue. The scan does not show diffuse uptake, which rules out Grave's disease.

 

Option D. Lateral aberrant thyroid: Incorrect as this condition involves ectopic thyroid tissue that might appear as functioning thyroid tissue outside the normal location. The scan does not indicate any ectopic thyroid tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypersecreting adenoma in the thyroid is characterized by increased radioactive uptake in one area of the thyroid with suppression in other areas, reflecting independent hormone production from the adenoma.

choices.text: Sodium outflow in thick ascending limb
Water outflow in thin descending limb
Sodium outflow in thin ascending limb
Flow of tubular fluid from PCT and DCT

questions.text: All of the following are components responsible for the countercurrent mechanism in the kidney except? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Flow of tubular fluid from PCT and DCT

 

Explanation

 

PCT and DCT is not a component of the countercurrent mechanism.

 

Countercurrent system has two divisions:

 

  1. Countercurrent multiplier formed by loop of Henle & Medullary CD
  2. Countercurrent exchanger formed by vasa recta.

 

The major factors that contribute to the buildup of solute concentration into the renal medulla are as follows:

 

  1. Ascending limb of loop of Henle - thick portion (Active transport) and thin portion (Passive transport) of sodium ions and co-transport of potassium, chloride, and other ions into the medullary interstitium
  2. Descending limb of loop of Henle – Passive transport of water from the tubules to interstitium
  3. Inner medullary collecting ducts - facilitated diffusion of large amounts of urea into the medullary interstitium

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium outflow in thick ascending limb: Incorrect as exclusion because it is a key component of the countercurrent multiplier, actively transporting sodium out of the tubular fluid.

 

Option B. Water outflow in thin descending limb: Incorrect as exclusion because it contributes to the countercurrent mechanism by allowing water to passively leave the tubular fluid, increasing its concentration.

 

Option C. Sodium outflow in thin ascending limb: Incorrect as exclusion; although less active than the thick segment, it still participates in sodium transport.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flow of tubular fluid from the PCT and DCT is not a component of the kidney's countercurrent mechanism, which primarily involves the loop of Henle and medullary collecting ducts in actively and passively managing solute and water concentrations to concentrate urine.

questions.text: GLUT2 is a glucose transporter that plays a significant role in maintaining glucose homeostasis. It is predominantly expressed in specific tissues, where it facilitates the bidirectional transport of glucose. In which of the following tissues is GLUT2 predominantly expressed? (FMGE  JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kidneys

 

GLUT2 is expressed in the kidneys, as well as in the liver, pancreatic β-cells, and small intestine. In the kidneys, it plays a role in the reabsorption and excretion of glucose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Skeletal muscle: Incorrect. Skeletal muscle predominantly expresses GLUT4, not GLUT2. GLUT4 is responsible for insulin-mediated glucose uptake in muscle tissue.

 

Option B. Adipose tissue: Incorrect. Adipose tissue primarily expresses GLUT4, which is responsible for insulin-mediated glucose uptake in fat cells.

 

Option D. Cardiac muscle: Incorrect. Cardiac muscle mainly expresses GLUT4, which is responsible for insulin-mediated glucose uptake in heart tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GLUT2 is primarily expressed in the kidneys, liver, pancreatic β-cells, and small intestine, facilitating bidirectional glucose transport.

questions.text:
Organize the listed bands within the sarcomere, starting from the periphery and moving towards the center. (INICET MAY 2023)

 

 

  1. Z line
  2. M line
  3. A band
  4. H zone
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1,3,4,2

 

The proper order of bands within the sarcomere, moving from the periphery towards the center, is as follows: Z line - I band - A band - H zone - M line.

 

 

Z line: A dense protein structure that separates one sarcomere from the next and serves as an anchor for actin filaments.

 

I band: The light-colored region in a sarcomere composed of only thin actin filaments.

 

A band: The dark-colored region in a sarcomere containing both thick myosin and thin actin filaments.

 

H zone: The central part of the A band where only thick myosin filaments are present.

 

M line: The center of the sarcomere, providing structural support and anchoring the myosin filaments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of bands within the sarcomere, from the periphery towards the center, is Z line, A band, H zone, and M line.

questions.text: A patient has a blood glucose level of 200 mg/dL and GFR of 90 ml/min. What is the amount of glucose excreted if the transport maximum of the patient is as shown below? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 30 mg/min

 

The amount of glucose excreted in the above scenario is 30 mg/min.

 

Calculation:

 

Step 1: Total filtered glucose calculated by GFR x Plasma glucose concentration

Here,

 

  • ﻿﻿GFR = 90 ml/min
  • ﻿﻿Plasma glucose concentration = 200 mg/dL= 2 mg/ml (1 dL=100 ml).
  • ﻿﻿Total filtered glucose = 90 ml/min X 2 mg/ml = 180 mg/min.

 

Step 2: Check transport maximum:

Here, as shown in the graph transport maximum is 150 mg/min.

 

Step 3: Calculate the excretion

 

  • Excretion = Total filtered glucose - Total reabsorbed glucose (Transport Maximum)
  • As calculated above, total filtered glucose is 180, Transport maximum is 150
  • = 180-150 mg/min = 30 mg/min is the excretion

 

Educational Objective:

 

Total filtered glucose=GFR × Plasma glucose concentration

Excretion=Total filtered glucose−Total reabsorbed glucose (Transport Max.)

choices.text: Volume of serum passing through kidney in 24 hours

questions.text: Which of the following is not required for calculation of creatinine clearance? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Volume of serum passing through kidney in 24 hours

 

The volume of plasma passing through the kidney in 24 hours is not used in the calculation of creatinine clearance.

 

Other Options:

 

The calculation of creatinine clearance involves the following parameters:

 

Option A. Urine creatinine concentration: This is the amount of creatinine present in the urine, typically measured in milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL).

 

Option B. Serum creatinine concentration: This is the amount of creatinine present in the blood, also measured in milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL).

 

Option C. 24-hour urine output: This is the total volume of urine produced in 24 hours, measured in milliliters (mL).

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Volume that remains in lungs after forced expiration

questions.text: Which of the following represents functional residual capacity? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Expiratory reserve volume + residual volume

 

Explanation

 

The functional residual capacity equals the expiratory reserve volume(1000-1100ml) + residual volume(1100-1200ml). This is the amount of air that remains in the lungs at the end of normal expiration (about 2300 milliliters).

 

Vital capacity - Total volume of air that can be forcefully expired after forceful inspiration


            = Tidal volume + inspiratory reserve volume + Expiratory reserve volume
 

 

Expiratory capacity – tidal volume + ERV

 

Residual volume (1100-1200) - Volume that remains after forced expiration

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Volume expired after normal inspiration: Incorrect as this description fits more closely with tidal volume, which is the normal volume of air displaced between normal inhalation and exhalation when extra effort is not applied.

 

Option B. Volume that remains in lungs after forced expiration: Incorrect as this specifically defines residual volume (RV), not the combination of ERV and RV.

 

Option D. Tidal volume + inspiratory reserve volume: Incorrect, this combination describes the inspiratory capacity, which is the total volume of air that can be exhaled after a maximal inhalation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the sum of the Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) and the Residual Volume (RV). It represents the volume of air remaining in the lungs at the end of a normal exhalation, ensuring continuous gas exchange between breaths.

choices.text: Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-
Passive Na+ reabsorption, active CI- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-
Passive Na+ secretion, active CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-
Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-

questions.text: The second phase of saliva secretion involves: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-

 

First, sodium ions are actively reabsorbed from all the salivary ducts and potassium ions are actively secreted in exchange for the sodium. Excess sodium reabsorption over potassium secretion, creates electrical negativity of about -70 millivolts in the salivary ducts; this in turn causes chloride ions to be reabsorbed passively. Therefore, the chloride ion concentration in the salivary fluid falls to a very low level, matching the ductal decrease in sodium ion concentration.

 

Active Na+ reabsorption

 

(The ductal cells actively transport sodium ions (Na+) from the saliva into the interstitial fluid surrounding the ducts. This reabsorption of sodium ions helps in concentrating the saliva). Conc.  15 mEq/L

              ↓

Passive Cl- reabsorption

(As sodium ions are reabsorbed, chloride ions (Cl-) passively follow along due to electrical charge balance. This results in the reabsorption of chloride ions from the saliva into the interstitial fluid). Conc.  15 mEq/L

              ↓

Active K+ secretion

(The ductal cells actively secrete potassium ions (K+) into the saliva. This secretion helps in maintaining the concentration of potassium ions within the saliva). Conc.  30 mEq/L

              ↓

Passive secretion of HCO3-

(Hydrogen carbonate ions (HCO3-) are passively secreted from the ductal cells into the saliva. This helps in maintaining the alkaline nature of saliva, which aids in buffering acidic substances and maintaining oral pH). Conc. 50 to 70 mEq/L,

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Active Na+ reabsorption, passive Cl- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-: Incorrect. While Na+ and Cl- processes are correct, K+ secretion is active, not passive.

 

Option B. Passive Na+ reabsorption, active Cl- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-: Incorrect. Na+ reabsorption and Cl- reabsorption roles are reversed, and K+ secretion is active.

 

Option C. Passive Na+ secretion, active Cl- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-: Incorrect. Na+ reabsorption should be active, not passive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The second phase of saliva secretion involves active Na+ reabsorption, passive Cl- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, and passive secretion of HCO3-, crucial for maintaining electrolyte balance and pH in saliva.

questions.text: Testosterone is secreted by? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Leydig cells

 

Leydig cells are specialized cells located within the testes that are responsible for the production of testosterone, the primary male sex hormone. This process is regulated by luteinizing hormone (LH), which is released from the anterior pituitary gland.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior Pituitary: Incorrect because the anterior pituitary secretes LH and FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone), which regulate the function of Leydig and Sertoli cells, respectively, but it does not directly secrete testosterone.

 

Option C. From the conversion of dihydrotestosterone: Incorrect as dihydrotestosterone (DHT) is actually derived from testosterone via the action of the enzyme 5α-reductase, primarily in peripheral tissues.

 

Option D. From Sertoli cells: Incorrect because Sertoli cells produce inhibin and androgen-binding protein under the stimulation of FSH, not testosterone.

 

Additional Information

 

  • Two-Cell–Two-Gonadotropin Theory: This theory explains the interaction between Leydig and Sertoli cells in the testes. LH stimulates Leydig cells to produce testosterone, while FSH stimulates Sertoli cells to produce inhibin and androgen-binding globulin, which help regulate the effects of testosterone on spermatogenesis.
  • Negative Feedback Regulation: Testosterone exerts negative feedback on the hypothalamus and anterior pituitary to inhibit the secretion of LH, and inhibin specifically inhibits FSH secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Testosterone is primarily produced by Leydig cells in the testes, under the regulation of LH from the anterior pituitary. This hormone is crucial for the development of male reproductive tissues, secondary sexual characteristics, and several other physiological functions such as muscle mass maintenance, bone density, and mood regulation.

choices.text: Risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with the degree of thrombocytosis
It is protective against H. pylori infection
Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK 2 mutation
Acute myeloid leukemia is the most common cause of mortality

questions.text: Which of the following statements about polycythemia vera is true? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK 2 mutation

 

Polycythemia vera (PV) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by the overproduction of red blood cells. It is commonly associated with a mutation in the JAK2 gene, which can also affect other cell types, including mast cells. Activation of these cells can lead to the release of histamine, which is thought to contribute to the itching or pruritus often experienced by patients, particularly after warm baths or showers.

 

Myeloproliferative neoplasms include PCV, CML, and PMF.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with the degree of thrombocytosis: Incorrect. Although thrombocytosis is present in polycythemia vera, thrombosis risk correlates more significantly with leukocytosis and the presence of JAK2 mutation rather than solely with thrombocytosis.

 

Option B. It is protective against H. pylori infection: Incorrect. There is no evidence to suggest that polycythemia vera provides protection against H. pylori infection. Patients with PV actually may have an increased risk of gastrointestinal issues.

 

Option D. Acute myeloid leukemia is the most common cause of mortality: Incorrect. While patients with polycythemia vera do have an increased risk of transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML), the most common cause of mortality in these patients is thrombotic events such as heart attack or stroke.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Generalized pruritus in polycythemia vera, exacerbated by warmth or bathing, is a well-known symptom related to mast cell activation due to the JAK2 mutation. This mutation is a hallmark of the disease and leads to several systemic effects, including increased histamine release, which contributes to pruritus.

 

All MPN can develop AML, Myelofibrosis in the course of the disease.

questions.text: Which mineral is important for sexual maturation? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Zinc

 

Explanation:

 

Zinc is the mineral most crucial for sexual maturation. It plays a significant role in several biological processes related to growth and development, particularly in the reproductive system. Zinc is essential for the stabilization of cell membranes and has anti-inflammatory properties. Moreover, zinc is crucial for the proper functioning and development of sperm, which directly links it to sexual maturation.

 

One of the key reasons zinc is important in sexual maturation is because of its role in the formation of zinc finger motifs. These motifs are a type of protein structure that binds to DNA and plays a vital role in gene expression, including genes involved in the development of sexual characteristics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selenium: Selenium is an essential trace element that plays a role in antioxidant defense and thyroid function. While it is important for general health, it is not as directly involved in sexual maturation as zinc.

 

Option B. Copper: Copper is important for various enzymatic reactions and the formation of red blood cells. Although it contributes to overall health, it is not specifically linked to sexual maturation.

 

Option C. Calcium: Calcium is critical for bone health and muscle function, but it does not have a direct role in sexual maturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc is the key mineral necessary for sexual maturation, particularly due to its role in the development and functioning of the reproductive system, including the formation of zinc finger motifs important for gene expression

questions.text: In which of the following conditions prolactin level is highest?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 24 hours after delivery

 

Explanation

 

Among the given options, the prolactin level is highest 24 hours after delivery.

 

This hormone is secreted by the mother’s anterior pituitary gland, and its concentration in her blood rises steadily from the fifth week of pregnancy until birth of the baby, at which time it has risen to 10 to 20 times the normal nonpregnant level.

 

  • 24 Hours After Delivery: Following childbirth, prolactin levels are significantly elevated to facilitate breastfeeding. These levels are particularly high immediately postpartum as the body prepares to produce milk to feed the newborn. This is the period when prolactin levels are typically at their highest among the given options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 24 hours after ovulation: Although hormonal changes related to the menstrual cycle do affect prolactin levels, these changes are moderate and do not typically reach the peak levels seen postpartum. The role of prolactin around ovulation is less pronounced compared to its surge after delivery, where it is critical for initiating and sustaining lactation.

 

Option C. NREM Sleep: Prolactin levels naturally rise during sleep, especially during the deeper stages of NREM sleep, due to reduced dopamine activity, which normally inhibits prolactin secretion. Despite this increase, the levels achieved during sleep are usually not as high as those observed after childbirth, where prolactin plays a direct and significant role in breastfeeding.

 

Option D. After running for 1 hour: Physical activities and stress can lead to an increase in prolactin levels as part of the body's response to physiological stress or exertion. However, these increases are generally transient and significantly lower than the sustained high levels required for lactation post-delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Other factors which leads to high prolactin levels (hyperprolactinemia) in the body are:

 

During sleep, the hypothalamus releases dopamine, which inhibits the secretion of jectiveprolactin. As the night progresses and sleep deepens, dopamine levels decrease, leading to a decrease in the inhibition of prolactin release. Consequently, prolactin levels rise, reaching their peak in the early morning hours.

 

Prolactinoma: The most common cause of hyperprolactinemia is a noncancerous tumour of the pituitary gland called a prolactinoma.

 

Medications: Certain medications can increase prolactin levels. These include antipsychotic (such as risperidone and haloperidol), antidepressants, anti-nausea drugs (such as metoclopramide), and some high blood pressure medications.

 

Hypothyroidism: Underactive thyroid gland (hypothyroidism) can disrupt the normal balance of hormones in the body, including prolactin regulation.

 

Chronic Kidney Disease: Kidney dysfunction or chronic kidney disease can lead to hyperprolactinemia. Impaired kidney function affects the clearance of prolactin from the blood, leading to elevated levels.

 

Stress and Emotional Factors: Extreme stress, emotional trauma, or intense physical activity can temporarily raise prolactin levels.

 

Pregnancy and Breastfeeding: During pregnancy, prolactin levels increase to prepare the breasts for milk production. After childbirth, prolactin levels remain elevated to stimulate and maintain breastfeeding.

questions.text: A pregnant lady comes to the OPD for a regular check-up. She has decreased iron levels and the doctor prescribed her iron medication. Which of the following decreases the iron absorption from the gut? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tea


Iron absorption in the gut is influenced by various dietary factors. Vitamin C, found in foods such as amla (Indian gooseberry), lemon juice, and sprouts, enhances iron absorption by converting ferric iron (Fe3+) to ferrous iron (Fe2+), which is more readily absorbed.

 

On the other hand, substances like tannins and polyphenols, which are abundant in tea, inhibit iron absorption.

 

When tea is consumed with meals, the tannins bind to non-heme iron (plant-based iron), forming insoluble complexes that are not easily absorbed by the gut. This reduces the overall bioavailability of dietary iron. Thus, drinking tea during or shortly after meals can significantly decrease iron absorption, which is particularly important to avoid in individuals with iron deficiency, such as pregnant women.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amla: Rich in vitamin C, amla enhances iron absorption by converting Fe3+ to Fe2+.

 

Option B. Lemon juice: A citrus fruit high in vitamin C, which aids in iron absorption.

 

Option D. Sprouts: Also high in vitamin C, promoting better iron absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tea contains tannins that decrease iron absorption from the gut by binding to non-heme iron and forming insoluble complexes.

questions.text:
The following Darrow Yannet diagram is suggestive of which condition? (AIIMS May 2018)

 

Note: The solid line is the original fluid compartment the dotted line denotes the change caused by the condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adrenal Insufficiency

 

Darrow Yannet diagrams are graphs that tell you the osmolarity and volume changes of body fluids. X axis represents volume. Y axis represents solute concentration.

 

 

 

Addison's disease is adrenal insufficiency. Aldosterone makes you retain sodium so in the absence of aldosterone, you will lose sodium.) so osmolarity of ECF will decrease. ECF volume will decrease as fluid will move from ECF to ICF, thus ICF volume will increase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excessive sweating: Generally leads to both sodium and water loss, reducing volume but potentially increasing or maintaining osmolarity.

 

Option C. Diarrhoea: Also causes loss of water and electrolytes but usually does not lead to a significant increase in ICF volume.

 

Option D. SIADH (Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone): Causes hyponatremia and increased ECF volume, opposite to what is seen in the diagram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenal insufficiency leads to a decrease in ECF volume and osmolarity due to loss of sodium and water, prompting a compensatory increase in ICF volume. This is visualized in the Darrow Yannet diagram by the shift from a higher solute concentration and volume to lower levels in the ECF and an increase in the ICF.

questions.text: After reaching an equilibrium state during exercising, it was found that the body was consuming oxygen at the rate of 1500 ml/min. Calculate the MET score if the baseline oxygen consumption at rest is 250 ml/min? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6

 

MET (Metabolic Equivalent) is a unit used to estimate the energy expenditure of physical activities as a multiple of the resting metabolic rate (RMR). One MET is equal to the energy expended at rest, which is approximately 3.5 mL of oxygen per kilogram of body weight per minute (ml/kg/min).

 

To calculate the MET score for a given level of oxygen consumption, we need to first convert the oxygen consumption rate from ml/min to ml/kg/min, and then divide it by the resting oxygen consumption rate to get the MET value.

 

Assuming an average body weight of 70 kg, the oxygen consumption rate of 1500 ml/min corresponds to 21.4 ml/kg/min (1500 ml/min ÷ 70 kg).

 

Dividing this value by the resting oxygen consumption rate of 250 ml/min, we get:

 

MET score = 21.4 ml/kg/min ÷ 3.5 ml/kg/min ≈ 6

 

Therefore, the correct answer is B. 6.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The MET score represents the energy expenditure of an activity as a multiple of the resting metabolic rate.

choices.text: Projection of adjacent fibers to overlap to right sensory cortex
Projection of adjacent fibers to overlap to left sensory cortex

questions.text: After a right limb amputation, the patient is experiencing severe pain (phantom limb). What is the mechanism behind this? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Projection of adjacent fibers to overlap to left sensory cortex

 

When a limb is amputated, the sensory input from that limb is lost. However, the brain's sensory cortex, which was originally responsible for receiving input from that limb, does not remain idle. Due to the phenomenon known as cortical plasticity, the brain adapts by allowing adjacent areas of the sensory cortex to project their fibers into the area that previously received input from the amputated limb.

 

Since sensory information from the right limb is processed in the contralateral (left) sensory cortex, it is the left sensory cortex that experiences changes. The adjacent fibers from neighboring cortical areas begin to overlap and take over the area previously occupied by the input from the now-amputated right limb. This can lead to the sensation of phantom pain, where the patient feels pain in the missing limb as the brain "misinterprets" signals from these newly connected areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Projection of adjacent fibers to overlap to right sensory cortex: This is incorrect because sensory input from the right limb is processed in the left sensory cortex, not the right. Therefore, changes due to cortical plasticity would occur in the left cortex, not the right.

 

Option C. Expansion of right sensory cortex: The concept of cortical expansion does not apply here. In cases of amputation, the cortex area corresponding to the amputated limb doesn't expand but rather is taken over by adjacent cortical areas. Also, any changes would occur in the left cortex, not the right.

 

Option D. Expansion of left sensory cortex: While the left sensory cortex is indeed involved, the term "expansion" is not accurate in this context. It is the overlapping projection of adjacent fibers that occurs, not an expansion of the cortex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cortical plasticity allows adjacent cortical areas to project into regions that have lost their original sensory input, such as after limb amputation. This often leads to phantom limb pain, where the sensation of the missing limb is still perceived.

choices.text: No cytoplasmic continuity between presynaptic and postsynaptic membrane
Connexons are involved in electrical synapse
Electrical synapse has more latent period than chemical synapse

questions.text: How is an electrical synapse different from a chemical synapse? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Connexons are involved in electrical synapse

 

 

Electrical synapses are characterized by direct open fluid channels that conduct electricity from one cell to the next. Most of these consist of small protein tubular structures called gap junctions (connexons) that allow free movement of ions from the interior of one cell to the interior of the next. By way of gap junctions and other similar junctions that action potentials are transmitted from one smooth muscle fiber to the next in visceral smooth muscle and from one cardiac muscle cell to the next in cardiac muscle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No cytoplasmic continuity between presynaptic and postsynaptic membrane: Incorrect. This statement describes chemical synapses, not electrical synapses.

 

Option B. Direction of impulse is unidirectional: Incorrect. Electrical synapses can conduct impulses bidirectionally, whereas chemical synapses typically conduct impulses unidirectionally.

 

Option D. Electrical synapse has more latent period than chemical synapse: Incorrect. Electrical synapses have a shorter latent period compared to chemical synapses due to the direct transfer of ions through connexons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Electrical synapses involve connexons, which are gap junctions that allow direct ion flow between adjacent cells, facilitating rapid and synchronized electrical communication.

questions.text: Which of the following component is absent in the smooth muscle? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Troponin

 

Smooth muscle, unlike skeletal muscle, does not contain troponin. In smooth muscle cells, actin and myosin are present and are essential for muscle contraction. Tropomyosin is also present in smooth muscle, though its role differs from that in skeletal muscle. While in skeletal muscle, tropomyosin blocks the myosin binding sites on actin filaments, its function in smooth muscle is still not completely understood but is thought to aid in muscle contraction. Troponin, however, is absent in smooth muscle.

 

In skeletal muscle, troponin binds to calcium ions during muscle contraction, facilitating the interaction between actin and myosin.

 

Smooth muscle uses calmodulin to bind calcium instead of troponin, enabling muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Actin: Actin is present in smooth muscle and plays a crucial role in the contraction process by interacting with myosin.

 

Option B. Myosin: Myosin is also present in smooth muscle and is essential for contraction as it interacts with actin.

 

Option C. Tropomyosin: Tropomyosin is present in smooth muscle. Although its exact role differs from that in skeletal muscle, it is involved in the contraction mechanism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Troponin is absent in smooth muscle; instead, calcium binds to calmodulin to facilitate muscle contraction.

questions.text: What causes the sharp drop in LH levels after ovulation? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Progesterone

 

Explanation:

 

Progesterone, secreted by the corpus luteum post-ovulation, triggers negative feedback on GnRH and LH secretion, causing the characteristic sharp drop in LH levels. 

 

This drop is crucial for:

  • Preventing multiple ovulations
  • Maintaining corpus luteum function
  • Supporting potential early pregnancy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Estradiol triggers LH surge pre-ovulation via positive feedback

 

Option B: FSH doesn't directly regulate LH levels

 

Option D: HCG only appears after conception

 

Educational Objective:

 

Progesterone's negative feedback on LH secretion is essential for normal menstrual cycling and early pregnancy support. Understanding this mechanism helps explain menstrual disorders and contraceptive mechanisms.

questions.text: The image below depicts which of the following types of cell-to-cells signaling? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Paracrine

 

Explanation

 

The given image shows the paracrine cell-to-cell signaling mechanism where signaling molecules released by a cell only affect nearby target cells.

 

An example of paracrine signaling is the release of endothelin-1, a potent vasoconstrictor released by the endothelial cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Autocrine: Incorrect. In autocrine signaling, a cell targets itself, releasing signals that bind to receptors on its own surface.

 

Option C. Endocrine: Incorrect. Endocrine signaling involves hormones that are released into the bloodstream and affect distant target cells.

 

Option D. Merocrine: Incorrect. Merocrine refers to a type of exocrine secretion where cells secrete substances via exocytosis; it is not a type of intercellular signaling but a mode of secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Entry of calcium into sarcoplasmic reticulum

questions.text: Myosin head detaches from actin by which of the following mechanism? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Binding of ATP

 

Binding of ATP on the free site of myosin leads to the detachment of myosin head from the thin filament.

 

 

Energy for movement of myosin head (power stroke) is obtained by breakdown of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) into adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and inorganic phosphate (Pi). Head of myosin has a site for ATP and itself can act as the enzyme ATPase and catalyse the breakdown of ATP.

 

Even before the onset of contraction, an ATP molecule binds with myosin head.

When tropomyosin moves to expose the active sites, the head is attached to the active site. Now ATPase cleaves ATP into ADP and Pi, which remains in head itself. The energy released during this process is utilized for contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entry of calcium into sarcoplasmic reticulum: Incorrect. The entry of calcium into the sarcoplasmic reticulum helps in muscle relaxation but does not directly cause the detachment of the myosin head from actin.

 

Option C. Change in troponin C configuration: Incorrect. The change in troponin C configuration exposes the active sites on actin for myosin binding but does not cause detachment.

 

Option D. Release of ADP and Pi: Incorrect. The release of ADP and Pi occurs after the power stroke but does not cause the detachment of the myosin head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The detachment of the myosin head from actin is caused by the binding of ATP to the myosin head, which is a critical step in the muscle contraction and relaxation cycle.

questions.text: The motor supply of the muscle spindle is which of the following? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gamma neuron

 

Gamma motor neurons specifically innervate the intrafusal fibers within the muscle spindles, adjusting their tension and sensitivity to stretch, which is crucial for proper proprioceptive feedback.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha (α) neuron: Alpha motor neurons innervate extrafusal muscle fibers, which are the main contractile units of the muscle, and are not involved in the direct control of muscle spindle sensitivity.

 

Option C. Beta (β) neuron: A Beta neurons are sensory in nature, so they neither supply extrafusal nor intrafusal muscle fibers.

 

Option D. Delta (δ) neuron: Delta neurons are sensory neurons that transmit pain, temperature, and coarse touch sensations. They do not provide motor supply to muscle spindles or any other muscle fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gamma motor neurons (A gamma) specifically innervate the intrafusal fibers of muscle spindles, adjusting their tension and sensitivity to stretch, which is crucial for proper proprioceptive feedback.

questions.text: As filtrate flows through PCT, the concentration of all of the following decreases except: (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chloride

 

Normally in the PCT, Glucose & Amino Acid maximally approx. 100% reabsorbed; Bicarbonate approx.-80-85% and about 60-70 per cent of the filtered load of sodium and water and a slightly lower percentage of filtered chloride are reabsorbed by the proximal tubule before the filtrate reaches the loops of Henle. Hence, the concentration of chloride relatively increases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amino acid: The concentration of amino acids decreases significantly as they are almost entirely reabsorbed in the PCT.

 

Option B. Glucose: Glucose concentration also decreases drastically due to nearly complete reabsorption in the PCT.

 

Option D. Bicarbonate: A large percentage of bicarbonate is reabsorbed in the PCT, leading to a decrease in its concentration in the filtrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

As filtrate flows through the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), the concentration of chloride increases relative to other substances, which are more extensively reabsorbed. This includes glucose and amino acids, which are almost completely reabsorbed, and bicarbonate, which is substantially reabsorbed.

questions.text: The relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to the segment with the bolus of food during peristalsis is because of? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) VIP

 

The relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to the segment with the bolus of food during peristalsis is due to the release of VIP (Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide) from the enteric nervous system.

 

VIP is a neuropeptide that is released by neurons in the myenteric plexus of the enteric nervous system. It causes relaxation of the smooth muscle in the intestinal wall, including the distal segment, through its action on VIP receptors located on the smooth muscle cells. This relaxation allows the bolus of food to move smoothly along the digestive tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Substance P: Incorrect. Substance P is a neuropeptide involved in the regulation of gastrointestinal motility, primarily stimulating smooth muscle contraction rather than relaxation.

 

Option C. Dopamine from adrenergic fibres: Incorrect. Dopamine from adrenergic fibers is involved in the regulation of gastrointestinal motility, but it is not specifically responsible for the relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to the bolus of food during peristalsis.

 

Option D. Acetylcholine from myenteric fibres: Incorrect. Acetylcholine from myenteric fibers is a neurotransmitter involved in the regulation of gastrointestinal motility, typically promoting contraction rather than relaxation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to the bolus of food during peristalsis is mediated by the release of Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide (VIP) from the enteric nervous system, which causes smooth muscle relaxation and facilitates the smooth movement of the bolus through the digestive tract.

choices.text: Intracellular fluid
Extracellular fluid

questions.text: A body fluid sample is being studied and has Na: 10 mEq/L, K: 140 mEq/L, CI: 4 mE/L. Identify the compartment from which the sample has been obtained? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Intracellular fluid

 

Explanation

 

The electrolyte composition in the sample obtained has high concentration of potassium, suggests that it is intracellular fluid (IC) compartment.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interstitial and Option C. Extracellular Fluid generally have higher sodium and chloride concentrations and much lower potassium concentrations.

 

Option D. Plasma, part of the extracellular fluid, would similarly show higher sodium and chloride but lower potassium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The composition of potassium, sodium, and chloride in the sample aligns with that typically found in intracellular fluid, reflecting its origin from within cells, where potassium is the major cation, unlike extracellular compartments dominated by sodium and chloride.

questions.text: Match the following molecules with their carriers in plasma: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

Plasma contains various components like ions, inorganic and organic molecules that help in the transport of substances across various parts of the body, such as Albumin, globulin, and fibrinogen fractions.

 

  1. Thyroxine is carried by transthyretin, also called thyroid-binding pre-albumin.
  2. Fatty acids are carried by albumin, which is a major carrier protein and osmotic regulator. It also transports hormones, amino acids, vitamins, and steroids.
  3. Hemoglobin binds to haptoglobin, which prevents free hemoglobin from being excreted in the urine.
  4. Heme binds with hemopexin for heme recycling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plasma transporters like prealbumin, albumin, haptoglobin, and hemopexin play crucial roles in the transport and recycling of thyroxine, fatty acids, hemoglobin, and heme respectively.

choices.text: A - Glucose, B - PAH, C - Bicarbonate and D - Inulin
A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D - PAH
A - PAH, B - Inulin, C - Glucose and D - Bicarbonate
A - Inulin, B - Glucose, C - Bicarbonate and D – PAH

questions.text: Identify the correctly matched pair of substances with their renal clearance from the graph given below? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D – PAH

 

The correctly matched pair of substances and their renal clearance is option B.

 

 

The concentration of the substance changes as it passes through the tubules. Removing the substance from the filtrate is k/a tubular reabsorption and adding more of the substance to the filtrate is k/a tubular secretion.

 

Amount of the substance finally excreted = Amount Filtered + Secreted - Reabsorbed

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the renal handling of different substances such as PAH, inulin, bicarbonate, and glucose is crucial for assessing kidney function and diagnosing various renal disorders. Each substance's behavior in the nephron informs clinicians about different aspects of renal physiology, such as filtration rate and tubular function.

questions.text: Which of the following disease pathogenesis primarily involves the marked structure: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paralysis agitans

 

The substantia nigra is the marked structure in the transverse section of the brain that is shown. Degeneration of the substantia nigra is observed in Parkinson's disease, commonly referred to as paralysis agitans.

 

Due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which aid in the manufacture of dopamine, the substantia nigra is pigmented. The substantia nigra lacks or has less pigmentation in Parkinson's disease.

 

Parkinson's disease is characterized by bradykinesia, stiffness, and resting tremors. It's also known as paralysis agitans due to the motor dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Depression: Incorrect because depression is typically associated with dysfunctions in other brain regions such as the prefrontal cortex and limbic system, not specifically the substantia nigra.

 

Option C. Alzheimer’s disease: Incorrect as Alzheimer's disease primarily involves the cerebral cortex and hippocampus, leading to amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles, rather than specific damage to the substantia nigra.

 

Option D. Huntington chorea: Incorrect because Huntington’s disease involves degeneration of the striatum and other parts of the brain but does not primarily affect the substantia nigra.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The substantia nigra's degeneration is central to the pathogenesis of Parkinson's disease, manifesting as motor symptoms like bradykinesia, stiffness, and resting tremors.

choices.text: Primary active transport
Facilitated diffusion
Simple diffusion
Secondary active transport

questions.text: Which of the following process is responsible for glucose absorption into the intestine?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Secondary active transport

 

Explanation   

 

Glucose is absorbed into the intestine by secondary active transport because this process allows for the efficient uptake of glucose against its concentration gradient.

 

Secondary active transport involves the coupled movement of two substances across a membrane, where the movement of one substance is dependent on the electrochemical gradient created by the movement of another substance. In the case of glucose absorption in the intestine, the secondary active transport mechanism relies on the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium pump.

 

The process of glucose absorption in the intestine occurs in the brush border membrane of the intestinal epithelial cells, specifically in the small intestine. Here's a step-by-step explanation of how secondary active transport facilitates glucose absorption:

 

  1. Sodium-Potassium Pump: The sodium-potassium pump actively transports sodium ions (Na+) out of the epithelial cells and into the intercellular space, using ATP energy. This creates a concentration gradient where the sodium concentration is higher outside the cell.
  2. Sodium-Glucose Cotransporter: The sodium gradient generated by the sodium-potassium pump is utilized by a specific protein called the sodium-glucose cotransporter (SGLT). This cotransporter binds both sodium ions and glucose molecules on the outer surface of the cell.
  3. Co-transport of Sodium and Glucose: As sodium ions bind to the SGLT protein, their movement into the cell down the concentration gradient provides the necessary energy for the simultaneous movement of glucose against its concentration gradient. Glucose is "dragged" along with the sodium ions as they enter the cell.
  4. Glucose Transporter: Once inside the epithelial cell, glucose is transported across the basolateral membrane (the inner surface of the cell) and into the bloodstream by facilitated diffusion through a specific glucose transporter called GLUT2.

 

Overall, the energy stored in the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium pump is used to actively transport both sodium and glucose into the intestinal epithelial cells. This secondary active transport mechanism allows for the absorption of glucose from the intestinal lumen into the bloodstream efficiently, even when the concentration of glucose is higher inside the cell than in the lumen.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary active transport: Incorrect because primary active transport involves the direct use of ATP to move substances against their gradient, which does not apply to glucose absorption in this context.

 

Option B. Facilitated diffusion: Incorrect as this method does not involve the active transport of glucose against its concentration gradient; it only allows movement along the gradient.

 

Option C. Simple diffusion: Incorrect because simple diffusion does not involve any transport proteins and occurs only along the concentration gradient, which is not sufficient for glucose absorption in the intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose absorption in the intestine occurs via secondary active transport, utilizing the energy from the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium ATPase to transport glucose against its concentration gradient. This process is crucial for efficient glucose uptake from the intestinal lumen into the bloodstream.

questions.text: In the adjacent graph phase Ib represents which one of the following property? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Plasticity

 

Correct. Plasticity refers to the ability of the bladder to accommodate increasing volumes of urine with little to no increase in intravesical pressure. The plateau phase (Ib) where the pressure remains relatively stable despite increasing volume is indicative of the bladder's plasticity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elasticity: Incorrect. Elasticity refers to the ability of a material or tissue to resume its normal shape after being stretched or compressed. In the context of bladder physiology, the initial part of the curve would represent elasticity as the bladder wall stretches without a significant increase in pressure.

 

Option C. Contractility: Incorrect. Contractility refers to the ability of the bladder muscle (detrusor muscle) to contract. This would be assessed during the voiding phase of the cystometrogram, not during the filling phase which is depicted in the graph.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect. One of the properties listed (Plasticity) does describe phase Ib of the graph.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phase Ib in the bladder pressure-volume graph represents the property of plasticity, where the bladder accommodates increasing urine volume with minimal increase in intravesical pressure.

choices.text: CCK - I cells, Duodenum and jejunum
Motilin - M cells, Duodenum and Jejunum

questions.text: Which of the subsequent pairs are inaccurately matched? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Motilin - M cells, Duodenum and Jejunum

 

Motilin is a gastrointestinal hormone produced by enterochromaffin cells and Mo cells (Not M cells) present in the stomach, small intestine, and colon.

M cells, or microfold cells, are specialized epithelial cells in the gut-associated lymphoid tissue (GALT) that play a crucial role in initiating mucosal immune responses, it does not release Motilin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrin - G cells, Antrum: Correct. Gastrin is produced by G cells located in the antrum of the stomach and stimulates H+ secretion by parietal cells.

 

Option B. Secretin - S cells, Duodenum: Correct. Secretin is produced by S cells in the duodenum and decreases gastric acid secretion while increasing pancreatic bicarbonate secretion.

 

Option C. CCK - I cells, Duodenum and jejunum: Correct. Cholecystokinin (CCK) is produced by I cells in the duodenum and jejunum, increasing pancreatic enzyme secretion and gallbladder contraction while decreasing gastric emptying and relaxing the sphincter of Oddi.

 

Option D. Motilin - M cells, Duodenum and Jejunum: Incorrect. Motilin is produced by enterochromaffin cells and Mo cells in the stomach, small intestine, and colon, not exclusively by M cells in the duodenum and jejunum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GIT HORMONES

 

  • Gastrin – G cell at antrum. Acts on Parietal cells stimulate the H+ K+ ATPase.
  • Secretin – S cells at Duodenum. Decrease gastric acid secretion and Increase pancreatic HCO3- secretion.
  • CCK-PZ – I cells in duodenum and jejunum. Increase pancreatic HCO3- secretion, Increase gall bladder contraction, Decrease gastric emptying and increase sphincter of Oddi relaxation.
  • GIP – K cells in duodenum and jejunum. Decrease H+ secretion and increase insulin release.
  • Motilin – Mo cells in small intestine. Produces migrating motor complexes (MMCs).

questions.text: A 72-year-old female presents with dyspnea and chest discomfort. She has a history of bronchiectasis and is on home oxygen. ECG shows the following rhythm. Which is the most appropriate initial management? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans: D) IV verapamil

 

Explanation: 

 

The ECG shows Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia (MAT) characterized by:

 

  • ≥3 different P wave morphologies
  • Irregular rhythm
  • Rate between 100-180 bpm
  • Associated with underlying pulmonary disease

 

Verapamil (CCB) is the first-line treatment as it:

 

  • Effectively controls ventricular rate
  • Is safer than beta-blockers in pulmonary disease
  • Doesn't suppress respiratory drive

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Amiodarone - Not indicated in MAT, may worsen pulmonary status 

 

Option B. Cardioversion - Ineffective in MAT as multiple foci are present 

 

Option C. Magnesium - While useful in some arrhythmias, not first-line for MAT rate control

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Identify the appropriate acute management of MAT, recognizing that rate control with calcium channel blockers is preferred over rhythm control strategies, particularly in patients with underlying pulmonary disease.

questions.text: Which of the following can be responsible for Bezold-Jarisch reflex? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Serotonin

 

Bezold-Jarisch reflex is the reflex characterized by bradycardia and hypotension, caused by stimulation of chemoreceptors present in the wall of left ventricles by substances such as alkaloids. It is also called coronary chemoreflex. Vagal fibers form the afferent and efferent pathways of this reflex.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Histamine; C. Prostaglandin and D. Angiotensin: do not involved in the Bezold-Jarisch reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serotonin, capsaicin, phenyl biguanide, and veratridine can cause Bezold-Jarisch reflex.

questions.text: A neuron is receiving 400 inputs from 150 sensory neurons. This is an example of? How would you categorize a situation where a single neuron receives inputs from 150 sensory neurons, totaling to 400 inputs? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Convergence

 

Convergence refers to the process by which multiple neurons synapse onto a single neuron, resulting in the integration of information from different sources. In this scenario, the single neuron is receiving inputs from 150 sensory neurons, indicating that there is convergence of input onto the single neuron.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Divergence: Divergence occurs when a single neuron sends its axon to synapse with multiple downstream neurons. This process spreads information from one neuron to many.

 

Option C. Feedback inhibition: This is a regulatory mechanism where a neuron sends a signal to inhibit its own activity indirectly through a network of intermediate neurons. It’s not relevant to the scenario described.

 

Option D. Feedforward excitation: This mechanism involves a neuron sending excitatory signals to downstream neurons to propagate an action potential. It’s not directly related to the scenario described.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Convergence is when multiple neurons synapse onto a single neuron, integrating inputs from various sources. In the scenario described, where one neuron receives inputs from 150 sensory neurons, convergence is the appropriate term.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a dietary fiber? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Milk

 

Explanation

 

Major components of dietary fiber are cellulose, hemicelluloses, D-glucans, pectin, lignin and gums. Cellulose, hemicelluloses and pectin are partially degradable, while other components are indigestible. Dietary fiber also contains minerals, antioxidants and other chemicals that are useful for health.

 

Sources of dietary fiber are fruits, vegetables, cereals, bread and wheat grain (particularly its outer layer).

 

Diet with high dietary fiber has health benefits since dietary fiber:

 

  1. Delays emptying of stomach
  2. Increases formation of bulk and soft feces and eases defecation
  3. Contains substances such as antioxidants and other useful substances

 

Diet with high fiber content tends to be low in energy and it may be useful in reducing the body weight.

 

Some components of dietary fiber also reduce blood cholesterol level and thereby decrease the risk for coronary heart disease and gallstones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cellulose: A primary form of dietary fiber found in the cell walls of plants.

 

Option B. Inulin: A type of soluble fiber found in many plants, used by some as a prebiotic to promote gut health.

 

Option C. Pectin: Another soluble fiber, pectin is commonly found in fruits and used to help gel liquids, also aiding in digestion and cholesterol reduction.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Junction of thick descending limb and DCT
Junction of thick descending limb and PCT
Junction of thick ascending limb and DCT
Junction of DCT and collecting duct

questions.text: Macula densa is made of specialized cells located at: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Junction of thick ascending limb and DCT

 

Macula densa are specialized cells in the end portion of thick ascending segment before it opens into distal convoluted tubule. It is situated between afferent and efferent arterioles of the same nephron. It is very close to afferent arteriole. Macula densa is formed by tightly packed cuboidal epithelial cells. It forms the part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Junction of thick descending limb and DCT: Incorrect. The macula densa is not located at the junction of the thick descending limb and the distal convoluted tubule.

 

Option B. Junction of thick descending limb and PCT: Incorrect. The macula densa is not found at the junction of the thick descending limb and the proximal convoluted tubule.

 

Option D. Junction of DCT and collecting duct: Incorrect. The macula densa is located before the DCT opens into the collecting duct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The macula densa is composed of specialized cells located at the junction of the thick ascending limb and the distal convoluted tubule (DCT), playing a crucial role in the juxtaglomerular apparatus.

choices.text: Decrease in partial pressure of oxygen
Both option a and b are correct
None of the above is correct

questions.text: What is the reason behind developing breathing difficulty at high altitudes? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Decrease in partial pressure of oxygen

 

  • The primary reason for breathing difficulty at high altitudes is the decrease in the partial pressure of oxygen (PO2). At higher elevations, atmospheric pressure is lower, which in turn decreases the PO2. This reduction leads to a lower oxygen saturation of hemoglobin in the blood, a condition known as hypoxia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease in hemoglobin concentration: Incorrect in this context. Hemoglobin concentration does not necessarily decrease at high altitudes initially; in fact, over time, the body may increase hemoglobin production as an adaptive response to chronic hypoxia.

 

Option C. Both option A and B are correct: Incorrect because only the decrease in PO2 is relevant in the immediate context of acute altitude exposure. Changes in hemoglobin concentration are more of a long-term adaptation.

 

Option D. None of the above is correct: Incorrect as option B accurately describes the reason for breathing difficulty at high altitudes.

 

Physiological Adaptations at High Altitudes

 

  1. Increased Ventilation: The body compensates for lower oxygen availability by increasing respiratory rate and depth (hyperventilation) to enhance oxygen uptake.
  2. Increased Red Blood Cell Production: With prolonged exposure to high altitudes, the body increases erythropoietin production, which stimulates the production of red blood cells, increasing the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood.
  3. Increased Hemoglobin Affinity for Oxygen: There may be physiological changes leading to an increase in hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, helping it to capture more oxygen under conditions of reduced PO2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Breathing difficulty at high altitudes is primarily caused by a decrease in the partial pressure of oxygen due to reduced atmospheric pressure, leading to insufficient oxygen availability and hypoxia. This challenges the body to adapt through various physiological mechanisms to maintain adequate oxygen delivery to tissues.

questions.text: All of the following are the core clinical features for the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Orthostatic hypotension.

 

Lewy body dementia (LBD), also known as dementia with Lewy bodies, is characterized by specific core clinical features. Orthostatic hypotension, while commonly observed in LBD due to autonomic dysfunction, is not classified as a core clinical feature but rather as a supportive feature for diagnosis.

 

Central feature: Dementia (Essential for the diagnosis of DLB).

 

Core Clinical criteria include the following:

 

  1. Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness.
  2. Recurrent visual hallucinations that are typically well formed and detailed.
  3. Rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder (RBD).
  4. Spontaneous cardinal features of parkinsonism.

 

Supportive Features of LBD:

 

  • Autonomic Dysfunction: Including orthostatic hypotension.
  • Severe Sensitivity to Antipsychotic Drugs: Patients may experience severe motor and neuroleptic sensitivity.
  • Other Hallucinations and Neurological Signs: Can include auditory hallucinations or transient, unexplained loss of consciousness.

 

Onset of dementia preceding or within 1 year of onset of parkinsonism differentiates Lewy Body dementia from Parkinson's disease with dementia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluctuating cognition: Fluctuating cognition is one of the hallmark symptoms of LBD, characterized by significant variations in attention and alertness. This fluctuation is more pronounced than what is typically seen in other forms of dementia, such as Alzheimer's disease, and can vary from hour to hour or day to day.

 

Option B. REM sleep behavior disorder: REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD) is a core feature of LBD, where patients physically act out their dreams, often vividly. This disorder is a result of the loss of normal muscle atonia that should occur during REM sleep, leading to potentially violent movements and vocalizations during sleep.

 

Option C. Recurrent visual hallucinations: Visual hallucinations in LBD are typically well-formed and detailed, often involving people or animals. These hallucinations are a core feature and differ from the more nebulous or less structured hallucinations seen in other disorders. They are thought to be due to the underlying Lewy body pathology affecting cortical brain areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orthostatic hypotension is a supportive, not core, criterion for the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia.

 

Reference - Harrison 21e/Neurology, DLB Chapter 434 /12305.

choices.text: Decrease in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure
Increase in glomerular capillary oncotic pressure
Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.text: Which of the following increases GFR? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure

 

Explanation:

 

Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) depends on net filtration pressure across the glomerular membrane. A decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure reduces opposition to filtration, thereby increasing GFR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure reduces the driving force for filtration, decreasing GFR.

 

Option B. Increase in oncotic pressure opposes filtration, decreasing GFR.

 

Option D. Decrease in renal plasma flow reduces the amount of plasma available for filtration, decreasing GFR.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure increases GFR.

choices.text: A - Cortisol B - Aldosterone C - Androgens D - Epinephrine
A - Aldosterone B - Cortisol C - Androgens D - Epinephrine
A - Epinephrine B - Cortisol C - Aldosterone D - Androgens
A - Aldosterone B - Epinephrine C - Androgens D - Cortisol

questions.text: Which hormones are produced from these zones? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A - Aldosterone B - Cortisol C - Androgens D - Epinephrine

 

Explanation:

 

The adrenal gland, located on top of the kidneys, consists of the adrenal cortex and the adrenal medulla. The cortex is further divided into three zones: the zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis. These zones are responsible for producing different types of hormones, remembered by the mnemonic "GFR."

 

  • Zona Glomerulosa (A): This outermost layer is responsible for producing mineralocorticoids, the most important being Aldosterone. Aldosterone plays a critical role in regulating sodium and potassium balance in the body.
  • Zona Fasciculata (B): The middle layer produces glucocorticoids, primarily Cortisol. Cortisol is involved in stress response, metabolism regulation, and immune function.
  • Zona Reticularis (C): The innermost cortical layer produces androgens, specifically DHEA (Dehydroepiandrosterone), which is a precursor to sex steroids like testosterone and estrogen.
  • Adrenal Medulla (D): The medulla produces catecholamines, primarily Epinephrine (adrenaline), which is crucial for the fight-or-flight response.

 

Educational Objective:


The adrenal cortex is divided into three zones—zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis—which produce aldosterone, cortisol, and androgens, respectively. The adrenal medulla produces catecholamines, primarily epinephrine

choices.text: Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

questions.text: C wave of JVP represents: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction
 

Explanation

 

'C' wave in JVP represents tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Contraction of right atrium: This is incorrect for the 'C' wave. The contraction of the right atrium produces the 'A' wave in the JVP, not the 'C' wave. The 'A' wave occurs due to atrial contraction pushing blood against a closed tricuspid valve at the end of diastole.

 

Option C. Passive filling of right atrium: Incorrect for the 'C' wave. Passive filling of the right atrium contributes to the 'V' wave, which occurs when the right atrium fills with blood during ventricular systole and the tricuspid valve is closed.

 

Option D. Passive emptying of right atrium: Incorrect for the 'C' wave. Passive emptying of the right atrium is associated with the 'Y' descent, which happens when the tricuspid valve opens in early diastole and blood flows from the right atrium into the right ventricle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Fig: Intra-arterial pressure changes during cardiac cycle. a, c, v= Positive wave x, x1, y= Negative waves

questions.text: A patient came following an RTA in the hospital. He is able to understand his friend’s talks. He is trying to speak (non-fluent aphasia) something to his friend. Which part of the brain is most likely to be injured? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Broca’s area

 

Explanation:

 

Broca’s area is responsible for speech production and language processing. It is located in the frontal lobe of the dominant hemisphere (usually the left hemisphere) of the brain. Injury to Broca’s area leads to Broca’s aphasia, also known as non-fluent aphasia. Individuals with this condition can understand spoken language but have difficulty in speaking, writing, or forming words properly.

 

Broca’s area: Broca’s aphasia is characterized by difficulty in speech production. The patient may understand speech but will struggle to speak fluently, often speaking in short, broken sentences with considerable effort. This condition is also known as expressive aphasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wernicke’s area: This area is involved in the comprehension of spoken language. Damage to Wernicke’s area results in Wernicke’s aphasia (fluent aphasia), where the patient can speak fluently but the speech is often nonsensical and lacks meaning.

 

Option B. Angular gyrus: This region is involved in various functions related to language, number processing, and spatial cognition but is not directly responsible for speech production or comprehension.

 

Option D. Arcuate fasciculus: This is a bundle of nerve fibers that connects Broca’s area and Wernicke’s area. Damage to this pathway can result in conduction aphasia, characterized by the ability to understand and produce speech but difficulty in repeating words or sentences.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Broca’s area is involved in speech production. Damage to this area results in non-fluent (expressive) aphasia, where the patient can understand speech but has difficulty speaking fluently.

choices.text: Primary active transport
Secondary active transport
Any of the above

questions.text: The mechanism by which glucose is absorbed in the intestine is? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Secondary active transport

 

  1. Glucose enters the lumen of the small intestine.
  2. Sodium ions (Na+) are present in the lumen of the intestine.
  3. Sodium-Glucose Co-Transporter 1 (SGLT1) on the luminal membrane of enterocytes facilitates glucose absorption:
    1. SGLT1 binds to both glucose and sodium ions.
    2. Sodium ions move down their electrochemical gradient into the enterocyte, providing energy for transport.
    3. Glucose molecules are co-transported with sodium ions into the enterocyte.
  4. Glucose enters the cytoplasm of the enterocyte.
  5. Inside the enterocyte, glucose can be used for energy or transported across the basolateral membrane.
  6. Glucose Transporter 2 (GLUT2) on the basolateral membrane of enterocytes facilitates glucose transport out of the cell:
    1. GLUT2 allows glucose to move down its concentration gradient.
    2. Glucose diffuses across the basolateral membrane into the bloodstream.
  7. Glucose is carried away by the bloodstream to various tissues and organs for utilization.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary active transport: Involves direct use of ATP for the movement of substances against their concentration gradient and does not apply to glucose absorption in the intestine.

 

Option C. Facilitated diffusion: Passive movement of molecules along their concentration gradient through a membrane protein, applies to the exit of glucose at the basolateral side but not to its uptake at the luminal side.

 

Option D. Any of the above: Not applicable as the specific mechanism for glucose absorption is secondary active transport.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose is absorbed in the intestine through secondary active transport utilizing the Sodium-Glucose Co-Transporter 1 (SGLT1), which couples the energetically favorable transport of sodium with the transport of glucose against its gradient into enterocytes.

questions.text: All of the following cause a right shift of the oxygen- hemoglobin dissociation curve, except? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased HbF

 

The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve describes the relationship between the partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) and the binding of oxygen to hemoglobin in the blood. A left shift of the curve indicates an increase in the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, resulting in more oxygen being bound to hemoglobin at a given PO2.

 

Increased HbF has a higher affinity for oxygen than adult hemoglobin (HbA), which causes a left shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve. This allows fetal hemoglobin to extract oxygen more efficiently from the mother's blood in the placenta, where the PO2 is lower than in the adult circulation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Factors causing a right shift (decreased affinity for oxygen):

 

Option B. Raised 2,3 BPG: Increased levels of 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate decrease hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen.

 

Option C. Acidosis: A decrease in blood pH (increased H⁺ concentration) reduces hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen.

 

Option D. Increased CO₂: Higher levels of carbon dioxide also decrease the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve shifts to the right with factors that decrease the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, such as increased 2,3 BPG, acidosis, and increased CO₂. In contrast, increased fetal hemoglobin (HbF) causes a left shift, indicating higher oxygen affinity.

choices.text: Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate
Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate→ Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release
Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal
Action potential at motor end plate → Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens

questions.text: Identify the correct order of End plate potential at the neuromuscular junction: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate

 

Explanation:

 

At the neuromuscular junction (NMJ), the sequence of events leading to muscle contraction begins with the binding of acetylcholine (Ach) to its receptors on the motor end plate. This binding opens ligand-gated Na⁺ channels, allowing an influx of sodium ions, which depolarizes the muscle membrane and generates an action potential. The action potential travels along the motor neuron to the axon terminal, where it triggers the opening of voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels. The entry of calcium ions into the axon terminal facilitates the exocytosis of Ach into the synaptic cleft, which then binds to receptors on the muscle fiber to propagate the signal for muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release:
This sequence incorrectly initiates with the opening of ligand-gated Na⁺ channels before Ach is released. In reality, Ach must first be released to bind to these channels and cause their opening. 

 

Option C. Ach Release → Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal:
Ach release is a result of Ca²⁺ entry, not the initial step. This option reverses the correct order of events.

 

Option D. Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens:
This sequence incorrectly places the action potential at the motor end plate before Ach release. The action potential at the motor end plate is a result of Ach binding, not the precursor to Ca²⁺ entry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence at the neuromuscular junction is:

 

Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate

choices.text: Degradation of retinoic acid by Cyp26b1 in primordial germ cells of males

questions.text: Hormone degradation as an important mechanism for regulating local concentrations is seen in? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Hormone degradation regulates local concentrations is seen in all of the above.

 

  • In renal tubular cells, glucocorticoids are inactivated by 11ß-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase.
  • Breakdown of retinoic acid by Cyp26b1 during development prevents meiosis in the male primordial germ cells.
  • The thyroid hormone 5’ deiodinases convert T4 to T3 and can inactivate T3 (Reverse T3) via 5 deiodinases.

 

Hormones are “cleared” from the plasma in several ways, including:

 

  1. Metabolic destruction by the tissues
  2. Binding with the tissues
  3. Excretion by the liver into the bile
  4. Excretion by the kidneys into the urine

 

Hormones are sometimes degraded at their target cells by enzymatic processes that cause endocytosis of the cell membrane hormone-receptor complex; the hormone is then metabolized in the cell, and the receptors are usually recycled back to the cell membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hormone degradation is a vital regulatory mechanism observed in various processes, including the inactivation of glucocorticoids by 11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase, the conversion and inactivation of thyroid hormones by 5 deiodinases, and the degradation of retinoic acid by Cyp26b1 in male primordial germ cells.

questions.text: The formula UV/P represents which one of the following renal functions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clearance

 

The formula UV/P is used to calculate the clearance of a substance in the kidneys. In this formula:

 

  • U stands for the Urinary concentration of the substance.
  • V stands for the Urinary volume or urinary flow rate.
  • P stands for the Plasma concentration of the substance.

 

Clearance refers to the volume of plasma from which a substance is completely removed by the kidneys per unit time. The UV/P formula is applied to determine how effectively the kidneys are clearing a particular substance from the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Filtration Fraction: This is calculated as the Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) divided by the Renal Plasma Flow (RPF).

 

Option B. Tubular secretion: This process involves the transfer of substances from the blood into the tubular fluid.

 

Option C. Tubular reabsorption: This process involves the movement of substances from the tubular fluid back into the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The formula UV/P is used to calculate the clearance of a substance by the kidneys, which reflects how efficiently the kidneys are filtering the blood.

choices.text: Segment la is due to residual urine
Segment II is due to Laplace law
Micturition fails to happen in segment II
The dotted line represents that micturition has occurred

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the given cystometrogram? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Segment II is due to Laplace Law

 

Explanation:

 

The true statement regarding the given cystometrogram is that segment lb is due to Laplace law.

 

The law of Laplace correlates volume and wall tension, is applicable to urine storage.

 

According to Law of Laplace, the pressure (P) in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension (T) divided by the radius (R). This is expressed as P= 2T/R.

 

As the bladder gets filled, the radius increases along with the tension, hence there is a slight increase in pressure until the bladder is relatively full, which explains the flatness of the graph in segment II

 

The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL. A marked sense of fullness is felt at a bladder volume of 400ml.

 

Cystometrogram is a plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of fluid in the bladder. The curve shows three segments:

 

 

  1. Initial Filling Phase (or Low-Pressure Phase): This phase represents the storage phase of bladder function.
  2. Rapid Filling Phase (or High-Pressure Phase): In this phase, the intravesical pressure increases more rapidly as the bladder volume reaches a certain threshold. The detrusor muscle, which contracts to initiate bladder emptying, starts to generate increased pressure as the bladder approaches its capacity. This phase represents the transition from storage to voiding phase.
